entry.title: âœš Visualization Tools and Resources, October 2025 Roundup
entry.summary: This is the good stuff for October. Tags: roundup

entry.title: America once made daylight saving time permanent. Hereâ€™s what went wrong.
entry.summary:
Horologist Lawrie Taprell adjusts the clock atop the North Sydney Post Office in Australia in 1989. Twice a year, clockkeepers like Taprell fine-tune public timepieces to match daylight saving shiftsâ€”something the U.S. once tried to make permanent. In 1974, the U.S. tried staying on daylight saving time all year. The result was darker mornings and public panic.
Love it or hate it, daylight saving time (DST) is one of the worldâ€™s most persistent experiments in tinkering with the sun. Roughly one-third of countries worldwide still practice it, but not without controversy.
In the United States, the federal government first standardized the twice-yearly clock change in 1966. Today, people in almost all U.S. statesâ€”with the exceptions being Hawaii and most of Arizonaâ€”â€œsprings forwaâ€¦

entry.title: Why York, England, may be the most haunted city in the world
entry.summary:
York reports a large number of ghost sightings, giving it a reputation as being one of the most haunted cities in Europe. From Roman ruins to candlelit alleyways, this walled city invites travelers to explore the chilling stories that linger where history and the supernatural meet.
Walking through the streets of York, England, feels a bit like traveling back in time. In one afternoon, you can walk among Roman ruins, check out the relics of Viking settlements, and stroll cobbled lanes with crooked medieval buildings. History comes alive in its Gothic cathedrals, Norman castle ruins, and cozy medieval pubs still serving up lagers and whiskeys today.
But what brings much of the visitors to Yorkâ€”particularly in the fallâ€”is its large number of ghost sightings, giving it the reputatâ€¦

entry.title: The comeback of Californiaâ€™s gray wolves just took a tragic turn
entry.summary:
For the first time in over a century, California wildlife officials have taken the drastic measure of legally killing four gray wolves after tensions with local ranchers reached a crisis point.
Earlier this month, the California Department of Fish and Wildlife captured and euthanized a breeding pair after months of complaints from ranchers over numerous livestock kills in a remote region of the Sierra Nevada mountain range known as Sierra Valley. The ultimate goal, according to the department, is to completely remove a seven-member pack called Beyem Seyo, one of 10 packs roaming the state. Two other Beyem Seyo wolves were also killed, and the agency plans to capture and relocate the remaining members to a wildlife sanctuary.
This particular pack has killed at least 87 cattle overâ€¦

entry.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors meet in emergency session on Sudan
entry.summary: Reports of mass atrocities in and around the newly-captured city of El Fasher in Darfur mark a new low in Sudan's brutal civil war and the Security Council is meeting in emergency session on Thursday morning in New York to address the rapidly deteriorating situation. Civilians are facing starvation and mass displacement as the UN continues providing lifesaving aid throughout the country. Hospitals, schools and IDP camps are under attack, with entire neighborhoods have emptied as families flee the RSF militia. Follow our in-depth live coverage; UN News app users can go here.

entry.title: This Colorado town inspired Disneylandâ€™s Main Street
entry.summary:
Fort Collins, Colorado, was part of the inspiration for Disneyland's "Main Street, U.S.A." Walt Disneyâ€™s vision of an idyllic â€œMain Street, U.S.A.â€ found a muse in the brick-lined charm of this community that is still ranked among the best places to live in the U.S.
When Walt Disney commissioned Harper Goff to help design Disneylandâ€™s Main Street, Goff didnâ€™t have to look far for inspiration. He found it in the brick facades and towers of his childhood hometown, Fort Collins, Colorado, with the buildingsâ€™ late Victorian era architectural details making their way into his 1951 sketches for Walt Disney. Goff poured his nostalgia for the simpler days of his childhood into every detail of Disneyland, ensuring that each child who visited could feel the same magic.
Fort Collins stilâ€¦

entry.title: Why America was so obsessed with Victorian â€˜ghost photosâ€™
entry.summary:
In 1862, jewelry engraver and amateur photographer William H. Mumler was developing a self-portrait in his Boston studio when a ghostly image began to surface. Just below his own image in the photo appeared a young woman in a flowing dress, her features blurred by a ghostly halo.
Mumler showed the picture to his friend, possibly as a joke, and mentioned the woman looked like his deceased cousin. Soon it was being passed through Boston society. It didnâ€™t take long for the local Spiritualist community to learn of the miraculous photo. The news was blasted to their followers via fringe religious journals: spirits had finally been captured on film.
In fact, the woman who appeared next to Mumler was likely Hannah Frances Green, who worked nearby as a photographer and spirit mediumâ€¦

entry.title: The science of why some spaces feel hauntedâ€”even when they're not
entry.summary:
Devoid of students and sound, this empty schoolhouse disorients the brainâ€™s internal mapping system, turning familiar architecture into a landscape of uncertainty. Scientists say such environments reveal how light, space, and silence can trick the senses into sensing danger where none exists. From looping hallways to echoing stairwells, eerie architecture taps into ancient survival instinctsâ€”and exposes how our brains map spaces to protect us from harm.
We often think of homes and hotels as safe, predictable spaces. Yet step into a corridor that stretches farther than your eyes can focus, and your pulse quickens before you even know why.
Scientists say these sensations arenâ€™t superstition but the brain misreading its surroundings. Experts reveal how architectureâ€”through walls,â€¦

entry.title: Caught on the RattleCam: unexpected snake behavior
entry.summary:
Two eastern garter snakes are shown. Scientists are finding that snakes exhibit more social behaviors than previously thought. For a long time, scientists didnâ€™t think snakes needed each other. New research proves that wrong. 
Picture an animal that huddles up with others when stressed, babysits its young, hangs out around relatives, and gathers in big groups every year.Â
Did you imagine a rattlesnake?
For a long time, scientists didnâ€™t think snakes could fit this description.
â€œThere were two big myths out there,â€ said Noam Miller,Â who studies animal social cognition at Wilfrid Laurier University. One is that snakes largely just operated on reflex. The other is that snakes donâ€™t gather in general, since people tend to only come across one snake at a time. â€œSo tâ€¦

entry.title: How to become a cowboy for the day in Scottsdale Arizona
entry.summary:
Since being bestowed the nickname the â€˜Westâ€™s most Western townâ€™ in the 1940s, Scottsdale in Arizona has become better known for its high-end resorts, spas and golf courses. But peel back the shiny top-layer of this cactus-studded city and you'll soon discover Western roots that run deep into the surrounding Sonoran Desertâ€™s rocky terrain. The cowboy spirit is evident throughout Old Town Scottsdale, in its lively saloons and Western-wear boutiques, as well as surrounding ranches and museums that showcase Scottsdaleâ€™s pre- and post-frontier past. From exploring sun-drenched landscapes on horseback to learning to triple-step in a Stetson, hereâ€™s how to embrace the cowboy lifestyle in Scottsdale.
Channel your inner John Wayne at the aptly named Arizona Cowboy College, a family-owned woâ€¦

entry.title: The chupacabraâ€”how evolution made a mythical monster
entry.summary:
The chupacabra incites fear and fascination, but scientists say the creature is likely a coyote with mange, like the one pictured here. Scientists say a common wildlife disease may be behind the chupacabra legend.
The chupacabra was first reported in Puerto Rico in the mid-1990s. Since then, tales of the mysterious canine-like monster that sucks the blood of livestock have incited fearâ€”and fascinationâ€”across Mexico, the U.S. Southwest, and even China.
But scientists say they can explain the stories with the help of evolutionary theory.
Reports of people spotting the flesh-and-blood chupacabras as recently as 2023 make the mythical creature eminently more accessible for study than, say, the Loch Ness monster or Bigfoot.
In almost all these cases, the monsters have turâ€¦

entry.title: The German eccentric who remade America's forests
entry.summary:
A portrait of Carl Alwin Schenck, the forstmeister whose work at the Biltmore Estate and the Pisgah National Forest, transformed the American landscape. A Gilded Age baron invited Carl Alwin Schenck to manage his forest at the Biltmore Estate. The decision changed America's landscape.
On a spring day in 1945, Christoph Rhoeneck perched at the edge of his familyâ€™s balcony. From the top floor of the brown, wood-clad house, in the middle of the southwest German mountain town of Lindenfels, he watched American tanks rolling up the valley below.Â
Rhoeneck, at the time around five years old, watched the United States Army knock down fences and drive over his neighborsâ€™ gardens, convoying along the villageâ€™s medieval road to the town center.Â
Now 85 years old, he remembers thinkâ€¦

entry.title: UN chief condemns Gaza killings, urges full respect for ceasefire
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General has strongly condemned the killing of civilians, including children, in Israeli airstrikes across Gaza overnight into Wednesday, calling for all parties to uphold their commitments to the fragile ceasefire

entry.summary: Myanmar stands at a crossroads between impunity and humanitarian crisis, as escalating military airstrikes, widespread civilian casualties and mounting evidence of war crimes continue to devastate the country.

entry.summary: Mounting nuclear risks â€“ from Ukraineâ€™s war-torn power plants to Iranâ€™s unresolved safeguards, and renewed inspection efforts in Syria â€“ are testing the global non-proliferation regime like never before, the UNâ€™s nuclear watchdog warned on Wednesday.

entry.title: South Sudan at risk of return to war, UN investigators warn
entry.summary: South Sudan faces a renewed slide into full-scale conflict unless urgent international action is taken, the UN-appointed independent investigative body examining human rights there warned on Wednesday.

entry.summary: What does it mean to build a society where everyone truly belongs? In a world increasingly shaped by digital divides, demographic shifts and climate disruption, the promise of â€˜social development for allâ€™ feels urgent, if elusive.

entry.summary: The UN General Assembly on Wednesday has â€“ for the 33rd consecutive year â€“ adopted a resolution calling for an end to the decades-long United States embargo against Cuba.

entry.summary: Developing countries are receiving less than 10 per cent of the money they need to adapt to a world increasingly vulnerable to extreme weather â€“ putting lives, livelihoods and entire economies at risk, the UN revealed on Wednesday.

entry.title: See the world's cities in a new light with these urban adventures
entry.summary:
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Why join a standard walking tour when there are plenty of novel ways to experience a city, and plenty of ways to indulge a niche interest? Visitors can get uncover New Yorkâ€™s musical history by diving into its punk scene; learn about the Cold War by driving a Trabant through Berlin; and get a unique perspective of Rio by paragliding above it.
The City of Lights shone brighter than ever last summer with its hosting of the Olympics â€” however, it also has a dark periphery that relatively few tourists seek out. The Petite Ceinture was a railway line with its origins in the mid-19th century. Abandoned since the 1980s, large sections have now been converted into official parks where you can wander among urban foxes andâ€¦

entry.title: At this English nature retreat you can birdwatch from bed
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Thereâ€™s never a bad time to visit Elmley Nature Reserve. In the cooler months, murmurations of starlings cloud crisp winter skies while tens of thousands of waders fill rain-fed pools. The beginnings of spring signal the swooping of lapwings and the boxing of hares, while summer lets loose a burst of butterflies and bees. Autumn is peak season for nocturnal birds, with migratory short-eared owls adding to the roster of barn owls, little owls and their long-eared cousins. And youâ€™ll find all of this perhaps where youâ€™d least expect: the briny marshlands on the southern end of the Isle of Sheppey on the Kent coast. Itâ€™s a clanking industrial heartland, jutting into the North Sea just 40 miles east of London â€” framed by pyâ€¦

entry.title: They mummified a human with ancient tools. It got messy.
entry.summary: The mummy of King Tutankhamun In an excerpt from his new book Dinner with King Tut, Sam Kean explores a weird and wild '90s experiment to replicate ancient mummification techniques. Excerpted fromÂ Dinner with King Tut: How Rogue Archaeologists Are Re-creating the Sights, Sounds, Smells, and Tastes of Lost Civilizations by Sam Kean. Copyright Â© 2025. Available from Little, Brown and Company, an imprint of Hachette Book Group, Inc. Cultures throughout history have mummified their dead, and a handful still do today, but Egyptian mummies remain the most iconic. Unfortunately, the Egyptians wrote down virtually nothing about their embalming process. This leaves experimental archaeology as one of the few avenues available for understanding mummification, and several â€¦

entry.title: In winter, Tasmania channels a surprisingly Nordic vibe
entry.summary:
The best time of year to see the southern lights in Tasmania is from May through September. Like Scandinavia, this remote island has built a culture around remoteness, creativity, slow living, and a deep respect for nature.
They may sit on opposite ends of the planet, one skirting the Arctic Circle, the other floating above Antarctica, but Tasmania and Scandinavia share more than just latitude extremes. In winter, this southern island channels a distinctly Nordic spirit: quiet, creative, and deeply connected to the natural world.
The parallels start with the landscape: glacial lakes, pine forests, wild coastlines. But they run deeper. Like Scandinavia, Tasmania has built a quiet culture around remoteness, creativity, and a deep respect for nature. Winter here isnâ€™t something tâ€¦

entry.title: This is what happens to your brain during menopause
entry.summary:
During menopause, women can experience forgetfulness, brain fog, and other cognitive symptoms. Over the years, studies have found that the end of menstruation comes with brain changes including shrinking brain volume and reduced blood flow. Researchers are delving into structural changes in the brain during the midlife transition.
Soon after she rounded 50, Susan Shaw noticed that things began slipping through her brainâ€”where she parked her car, who she needed to call, even the birthday of her best friend. An avid multitasker at work, suddenly the smallest disruptions threw her off. In the five years since, the problem has worsened.Â
â€œMy brain works differently now than it used to,â€ Shaw says. She compensates by creating elaborate to-do lists and asking coworkers not to interrâ€¦

entry.title: Avocados and monarch butterflies are on a collision course
entry.summary:
After their long journey south, monarch butterflies gather by the millions in a high-elevation fir forest of El Rosario Sanctuary, part of the Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve in MichoacÃ¡n, Mexico. Climate change and illegal deforestation for avocado production are threatening monarch butterfly ecosystems.
The flapping wings of millions of monarch butterflies at theÂ Monarch Butterfly Biosphere ReserveÂ in MichoacÃ¡n, Mexico, create a fluttering sound that Alfonso Alonso describes as â€œmagical.â€Â
The butterflies migrate from the northern United States and southern Canada each year just in time for DÃ­a de los Muertos on November 1 and 2, when celebrations in many parts of Mexico honor deceased ancestors.Â
The serendipitous timing may have led to the belief that a monarâ€¦

entry.title: 10 night sky events to see in November
entry.summary:
A super â€œbeaver moonâ€ rises behind Monte Prena in Italyâ€™s Apennine Mountains in November 2024. This yearâ€™s â€œbeaver moonâ€â€”the largest full moon of 2025â€”kicks off a dazzling month of celestial events, from meteor showers to bright planets lighting up the night sky. The month brings a spectacular lineup of celestial sightsâ€”including a rare chance to see Mercury without a telescope and a "micro" new moon.
November kicks off with Mercury making a brilliant evening appearance, then continues with not one, but three meteor showers. The largest full moon of the year rises early in the month, while a later â€œmicroâ€ new moon offers ideal darkness for harder-to-spot constellations like Orion and Taurus.
Here are 10 celestial events to watch for in Novemberâ€”and when to look up to catch theâ€¦

entry.title: World enters â€˜new eraâ€™ of climate action â€“ but progress must accelerate
entry.summary: While urging countries to accelerate action, UN Climate Change Executive Secretary Simon Stiell struck an optimistic tone on Tuesday following the release of a new report on updated national climate commitments.

entry.title: Gaza: Humanitarian response scaled up amid faltering ceasefire
entry.summary: Aid teams in Gaza are racing to meet urgent needs with tens of thousands still displaced, sheltering in damaged buildings and makeshift sites, while reports of renewed fighting between Israeli forces and Hamas threaten to derail the ceasefire.

entry.title: Hurricane Melissa: UN launches sea-lift operation to deliver aid
entry.summary: As Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in Jamaica as a category 5 storm, agencies continue mobilising supplies to support affected communities, with one senior official on the island telling UN News that Government-led preparations have been nothing short of â€œextraordinaryâ€.

entry.summary: The chair of an independent commission investigating alleged human rights abuses in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, told a General Assembly committee on Tuesday that Israel has committed â€œfour genocidal actsâ€ in Gaza, while leaders had â€œincited the commission of genocide.â€

entry.title: â€˜Horrificâ€™ violence as thousands flee Sudan's El Fasher
entry.summary: After 500 days of siege, the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia have reportedly taken control of the key Sudanese city of El-Fasher in Darfur, triggering widespread fear among families, and forcing thousands of civilians to flee.

entry.title: 10 must-see sights in South Africa that most travelers miss
entry.summary:
A group of dolphins creates a network of air bubbles to trap sardines before launching an attack. The African sardine run is when millions of sardines lay their eggs in the cold waters of the Agulhas shoal and then move north along the eastern coast of South Africa. From visiting ancient rock art to sipping wine while on safari, here are the best things to see outside of the most touristed hot spots.
From ancient rock art and epic mountain trails to spicy food scenes and safaris without the crowds, South Africa overflows with sights and activities for tourists. Yet, despite the country being nearly twice the size of Texas, just two destinations dominate touristsâ€™ agenda: the coastal city of Cape Town and the famous Kruger National Park. Theyâ€™re undeniable highlights, but tourists aâ€¦

entry.title: Top 10 things to know about the Day of the Dead
entry.summary:
Day of the Dead, or DÃ­a de los Muertos, is not a Mexican version of Halloween.
Though related, the two annual events differ greatly in traditions and tone. While Halloween embraces terror and mischief on the last night of October, Day of the Dead festivities unfold over the first two days of November in an explosion of color and life-affirming joy.
Sure, the theme is death, but the point of Day of the Dead is to honor the dead by demonstrating love and respect for deceased family members. In towns and cities throughout Mexico, revelers don funky makeup and costumes, hold parades and parties, sing and dance, and make offerings to lost loved ones. What is Day of the Dead?Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) is a celebration of life and death that originated in Mexico. It is noâ€¦

entry.title: Scientists reveal the secret of toads that can turn neon yellow
entry.summary:
As the first monsoon rains in India and southeast Asia begin to swell each year, one type of toad experiences an almost literal glow up. A temporary, hormone-induced wardrobe change transforms male Asian common toads (Duttaphrynus melanostictus) from chocolate pudding brown to lemon yellow in a matter of minutes.Â Â
While the femalesâ€™ skin remains brown, males undergo a color palette makeover to get ready for a lightning round of speed dating. Scientists have long known that the color change coincided with a frenzied, annual two-day breeding event, but they only recently confirmed the specific role it plays.Â
To investigate, researchers from SchÃ¶nbrunn Zoo in Vienna 3D printed toads â€” some brown, some yellow â€” and placed them amid real toads gathering to mate. They found that the â€¦

entry.title: The essential guide to visiting Cairo
entry.summary:
Khan Al-Khalili on Al-Muizz Street is Cairoâ€™s most famous souk (market), and has been trading rugs, lamps, gold, and jewelry for 600 years. The Pyramids of Giza, medieval markets, and the legendary Nile are just a few highlights of Egyptâ€™s energetic capital. Hereâ€™s our guide to where to stay, what to eat, and what to know before you visit Cairo.
Fueled by sugar and caffeine, Cairo is a late-night city, and the energy in both its ancient heart and wealthy â€˜Newâ€™ Cairo is boundless. A city with layers of history; the top drawcards are its most ancient: the Nile River and the Pyramids of Giza, which have towered over this frenetic megalopolis for millennia. And documented stories of Egyptâ€™s empires and eras are on display in a collection of museums spearheaded by the newÂ Grand Egyptianâ€¦

entry.title: What destroyed Napoleonâ€™s army?
entry.summary: Researchers recently found evidence that some of the soldiers who died during Napoleon's retreat from Moscow may have suffered from relapsing fever, caused by the bacteria species Borrelia recurrentis, and paratyphoid fever, caused by a strain of Salmonella. A new genetic analysis of teeth from a mass grave in Lithuania reveals hidden illnesses that plagued the French emperor's soldiers during their disastrous 1812 retreat. As French general and ruler Napoleon Bonaparte returned from a disastrous attempt to conquer Russia in 1812, his army lost tens of thousands of menâ€”many of them conscripted by forceâ€”to a fatal combination of extreme cold, exhaustion, starvation and disease. Based on reports from the time, the main diseases thought to have caused â€¦

entry.title: What makes Appalachian ghost stories so scary?
entry.summary:
TikTok may have led you to believe that Appalachia is populated by an inexhaustible supply of boogers, haints, witches, cryptids. But folklorists say most of the social media videos reveal a fundamental misreading of the region's ghost stories. Very little of the chatter on social media takes up the real lore that makes the region so rich in spooky storytelling.
In the early winter months of 1897, a woman named Mary J. Heaster found herself in regular prayer. Her daughter, Elva Zona Heaster Shue, had just died that January. Only recently married, Zona (as she was known) was a young woman, and her â€œdeath by heart diseaseâ€â€”as the county coroner had determinedâ€”weighed heavily on Mary. Had the coroner gotten the cause of death wrong? Mary prayed that her daughter would return to guide â€¦

entry.title: Why hurricanes are getting more powerfulâ€”more quickly
entry.summary:
As oceans grow warmer, theyâ€™re creating conditions that allow hurricanes to undergo rapid intensificationâ€”when a hurricaneâ€™s wind speed increases by 35 mph or more within 24 hours. Hurricane Melissa is the latest examples of this phenomenon.
Hurricane Melissa grew from a tropical storm to a powerful Category 5â€”90mph and in the span of 48 hoursâ€”and forecasters predict the storm could cause catastrophic flash flooding, life-threatening landslides, and extremely strong winds across the Caribbean.Â Hurricane Melissa is set to make landfall in Jamaica early Tuesday as a Category 5 storm, making it theÂ strongest hurricaneÂ to hit the island since record keeping began in 1851.
These types of explosive jumps have become more common in recent years, with devastating consequences.Â
Befoâ€¦

entry.title: See Brazil's outdoors through its greatest natural wonders
entry.summary:
Otherworldly LenÃ§Ã³is Maranhenses National Park is known for its flooded sands. Brazilian landscapes are known for their drama, with thundering waterfalls, rippling sand dunes and even a Grand Canyon all lying within the countryâ€™s borders.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Home to both the worldâ€™s largest rainforest and mightiest waterfall â€” the Amazon and Iguazu Falls, respectively â€” Brazil is a place of superlatives when it comes to natural wonders, from flooded sand dunes and soaring mountains to archipelagos covered with thick forest.
Brazilâ€™s vast ecosystems range from tropical wetlands to dry scrublands, plunging canyons to soaring plateaus â€” and between them, they make a home for an incredible 15â€“20% of all the plant and animal speciâ€¦

entry.title: World News in Brief: Funding cuts curb development, human rights in Belarus update, Ebola and mpox in Africa
entry.summary: Sharp declines in global aid are undermining decades of human rights and development progress, the UN Deputy High Commissioner for Human Rights, Nada Al Nashif, warned on Monday.

entry.summary: Millions of people across the Caribbean are bracing for the impact of Hurricane Melissa as it reached Category 5 status on Monday â€“ the most powerful on the scale â€“ defined by sustained winds of at least 157 mph (252 kmh).

entry.title: Children at risk as winter looms amid renewed strikes in Ukraine
entry.summary: Airstrikes and ongoing conflict in Ukraine are leaving civilians â€“ including thousands of children â€“ without homes, power, water and basic services, as humanitarians warn the approaching winter is heightening the risks for communities along the frontlines.

entry.title: Russian army committing murder in Ukraine: Independent rights commission
entry.summary: Drones operated by Russian forces have repeatedly attacked Ukrainian civilians, causing deaths, injuries and large-scale destruction, independentÂ UN human rights investigators said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Desperate need for water and food continues as Gaza families head north
entry.summary: More than 470,000 movements by civilians heading north inside the Gaza Strip have been recorded since the ceasefire began, said the UN aid coordination office (OCHA) on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Risk of large-scale atrocities in Sudanâ€™s El Fasher grows â€˜by the dayâ€™
entry.summary: Grave atrocities, including summary executions are reportedly being carried out in the Darfuri regional capital of El Fasher by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia, according to the UN human rights office (OHCHR).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: In Southeast Asia, Guterres presses the case for climate action
entry.summary: Amid deepening global divides and economic uncertainty, the United Nations called for stronger multilateral cooperation and sweeping reforms to global financial and governance systems, emphasising the need for a â€œnetworked, multipolar worldâ€ where equity and inclusion guide decision-making.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Aid cuts shutdown or suspend one in three womenâ€™s anti-violence programmes
entry.summary: Funding cuts are dismantling the frontline organisations working to end violence against women and girls, the UNâ€™s gender equality agency warned on Monday.

entry.title: An inside guide to Ã‰vora, Portugalâ€™s soulful university city
entry.summary:
Ã‰vora, 83 miles east of Lisbon, is a small, medieval-walled city with a grand sense of history. The seat of the Portuguese royal family in the 15thÂ and 16thÂ centuries, its littered with historic sites, from Roman to the remains of palaces. Now, itâ€™s gearing up to step into the spotlight as a European Capital of Culture in 2027, with exhibitions, residencies and performances in the works. But even with this buzz, at heart it remains a low-key, laidback place.
Begin your exploration at the cityâ€™s masterpiece, the Cathedral of Ã‰vora, whose 12th-century towers dominate the skyline. This brooding building is a mix of gothic and romanesque styles, best experienced by climbing to its roof for views across terracotta-topped neighbouring buildings and sunlit plains.
Steps away is the â€¦

entry.title: I've dined in Tuscany for over 20 yearsâ€”this is where to eat in autumn
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Although Tuscany is often associated with balmy summer days and the incessant cacophony of cicadas, itâ€™s in the colder months that its food truly sings. As temperatures drop in October, thereâ€™s a sense of respite after the long, languid months of searing heat. Autumn is a season of hard work, when everything Tuscanyâ€™s fertile lands have to offer is harvested and transformed into produce celebrated the world overâ€”ruby-red wines, thick, acid-green new olive oil, plump porcini mushrooms, and musky white truffles. In the mountains, chestnuts fall and are roasted over open flames, their sweet flesh kissed with smoke. Contrary to the meat-heavy image of Tuscan cooking, vegetables, beans, and pulses are central, earning localsâ€¦

entry.title: Which is the best island in southeast Asia for you?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Any Southeast Asian adventure, whether a shorter trip or a cross-country odyssey, will likely take in some of the regionâ€™s 25,000-plus islands. Youâ€™ll find plenty of coral-sand bays, seaside bars and swaying palms no matter where you go, but thereâ€™s far more to see beyond the beaches. Indonesia and the Philippines are entire island nations built on millennia of history, with countless Indigenous peoples and languages, and architecture that honours the gods. On the islands of Vietnam, Malaysia, Thailand and even landlocked Laos, youâ€™ll find thrilling scenery, fragrant street-food markets and irresistible villages. Here are eight of the best to explore.
Best for: beaches Thailand travellers escaping The White Lotusâ€¦

entry.title: Colossal crabs may hold clue to Amelia Earhart fate
entry.summary:
Amelia Earhartâ€™s fate may be tied to the giant coconut crabs of Nikumaroro, in Kiribati.
Members of the National Geographic-sponsored expedition that last searched the island for traces of the pilotâ€”famous for being the first woman to fly solo across the Atlanticâ€”knew to keep a wary eye out for the enormous crustaceans.
Adult coconut crabs are longer than a reporterâ€™s notebook, wider than an archaeologistâ€™s trowel, and roughly the same size as an explorerâ€™s hiking boot. As the largest land invertebrate on the planet, coconut crabs can measure up to three feet across and clock in at over nine pounds. In short, they are too big.
During the day, when expedition scientists do most of their work on the Pacific oceanic atoll, the crabs are easily avoided. Those that emerge froâ€¦

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in Istanbul
entry.summary:
The palatial skyline of this ancient Silk Road capital features stays for all kinds of travellers. One of the world's most visited cities, Istanbul offers a wide range of hotels, from palatial seaside mansions to luxury shipyard conversions.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Stretching across two continents separated by the Bosphorus Strait, this ancient Silk Road city was once the capital of both the Christian Byzantine and Islamic Ottoman empires. Crumbling hammams rub shoulders with striking contemporary buildings, while the call to prayer from Hagia Sophia mosque can be heard from the 15th-century Grand Bazaar, as well as Michelin-starred restaurants. Istanbul is sewn together by a series of storied districts, which results in a varied hoteâ€¦

entry.title: This spa town is perfect for exploring the UK's Peak District
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Perched on the edge of the Peak Districtâ€™s uplands, Buxton wears its heritage on its sleeve. Its Georgian crescents and Victorian halls recall an era when visitors came to â€˜take the watersâ€™ from mineral springs that still flow today. Itâ€™s an old market town, and the centre remains full of independent shops and cafes. Take a day to explore on foot; little details reveal themselves as you go, whether itâ€™s the splash of a pond in the Botanical Conservatory or the curve of a terrace in the glow of golden hour. The surrounding corner of Derbyshire has more architectural highlights, including grand stately homes just a 30-minute drive away. But Buxtonâ€™s biggest calling card is perhaps its location at the doorstep of the Peak â€¦

entry.title: Inside the fight to protect Canadaâ€™s most iconic bays
entry.summary:
A family of polar bears walks along the shoreline in Arviliit, also known as the Ottawa Islands, in northern Canada. In 2022, National Geographic Pristine Seas partnered with Oceans North for an expedition to the Canadian Arctic in support of Indigenous-led conservation. The expedition spanned seven weeks and 7,000 miles. A new documentary from the National Geographic Society and Oceans North spotlights how Inuit and Cree communities are creating marine protected areas in Canadaâ€™s north.
Flocks of geese soar through the sky in iconic V-formations, honking loudly. Wearing a matching camouflage jacket and pants, and a gun slung across his back, Edward Bearskin lifted his hands to his mouth and produced a convincing goose call. â€œI hunt geese for life. Itâ€™s part of my culture,â€ says Beâ€¦

entry.title: When the women of Iceland took a day offâ€”and inspired the world
entry.summary:
The morning of October 24, 1975, started out differently than usual for 90 percent of women in Iceland. For once, they didnâ€™t have the usual rush to make breakfast or get the children ready for school. The 60 percent of women who worked outside the home would not be going to their jobs either. They were going outâ€”and leaving the men in their lives to fend for themselves.
The women of Iceland took to the streets that day 50 years ago to protest unfair employment practices, the wage gap, and the general devaluing of domestic labor. Without them, everyday life ground to a halt. Nurseries and schools shut down without their female workforces, as did big shops, theaters, and fishing factories. Men were forced to bring their children to the office and, later that day, easy-to-cook sausages â€¦

entry.title: 8 big cities with extraordinary green spaces
entry.summary:
Trade the concrete of downtown for a lush park to help calm your mind, a good habit for both locals and travelers. These urban oases, in cities from Barcelona to Tokyo, provide a calming break from the bright lights and crush of the crowds.
My family of five loves traveling to large cities, but the crowds, noise, and unpleasant smells can sometimes be overwhelming. Thatâ€™s why, whenever we visit a city, we always make time to relax in a green space like a park or botanical garden.
Research shows that green spaces can help you de-stress from the city experience, explains Sandi Schwartz, author of Finding Ecohappiness: Fun Nature Activities to Help Your Kids Feel Happier and Calmer. â€œThe farther you get from the noisy urban center, the more nature acts as a buffer and helps you râ€¦

entry.title: The ghost stories of ancient Rome
entry.summary:
The goddess Roma appears to Julius Caesar on the banks of the Rubicon. One of the most common genres of ancient Roman supernatural stories was the appearance of spectral figures like this one. Ghosts stories appear in several surviving texts from ancient Rome. What do they reveal about the people who told them?
Do you believe in ghosts? Thatâ€™s what prominent Roman lawyer and statesman Pliny the Younger asked his friend in a letter around A.D. 100.
â€œI should very much like to know whether you think there are such things as ghosts,â€ Pliny wrote, â€œand whether they have their own shapes and some divine existence, or whether they are unreal images that take their forms from our own anxieties.â€
Pliny was writing to his friend Sura, a Roman senator. To give Sura some food for thâ€¦

entry.title: NASA discovered a bacteria that can â€˜play deadâ€™
A 100-mile journey along Switzerlandâ€™s dinosaur highway
entry.summary:
Thousands of dinosaur footprints can be found in the Jura Mountains, a range between Switzerland and France. In Switzerlandâ€™s Jura Mountains, ancient limestone holds thousands of dinosaur footprints. A gravel route traces their path across ridges, valleys, and 150 million years of history.
We spot the first cliff early in the morning. The summer sun rises slowly, its deep indigo gradually fading into a soft peach. The world remains asleep, and we break the silence with heavy breathing and the sound of our tires crunching on the gravel road beneath us.
In the distance, the Alps glowâ€”but we are traveling through the Jura, a lesser-known mountain range that separates northwest Switzerland from France. The Jura are lower and gentler than the Alps and mostly covered in forests. Theâ€¦

entry.title: These manuscripts brought Medieval beasts to life
entry.summary:
In the second or third century A.D., an anonymous author in Alexandria, Egypt, composed a text entitled Physiologus, or The Naturalist. The work was soon widely copied and comprised of 48 or 49 chapters. Each was dedicated to a specific animal and included an illustration, a description of its characteristics, and a storyâ€”part natural observation, part imaginative anecdoteâ€”about its behavior.
One such story, for example, features the lion. It was said that lion cubs were born lifeless and watched over by their mother until the father, king of the beasts, arrived and breathed life into them. This image gave rise to an allegorical reading steeped in Christian symbolism: the cub revived by the lion became a figure of Christ resurrected on the third day. While the lion embodied noble virtâ€¦

entry.title: World News in Brief: 80th birthday greetings, South Sudan floods, South Lebanon update
entry.summary: Marking its 80th anniversary, the United Nations celebrated decades of multilateral cooperation for peace, human rights, and sustainable development through events across the globe.

entry.title: UN warns Gazaâ€™s displaced face freezing nights and food shortages
entry.summary: The UN and its partners are accelerating deliveries of life-saving aid across Gaza, but relief efforts remain constrained by access restrictions and overwhelming humanitarian needs, officials said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Let's finish the jobâ€™ and end polio: WHO
entry.summary: Thirty-five years ago, polio, a highly infectious viral disease, paralysed around 350,000 children per year. Following a UN-led international push, that number is now less than 50.

entry.title: Guterres calls for urgent reform of the Security Council
entry.summary: Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres on Friday warned that the â€œfragileâ€ legitimacy of the Security Council could endanger global peace if it remains gridlocked and fails to fulfil its primary purpose.

entry.title: Santoriniâ€™s volcano is hiding an explosive secret
entry.summary:
A man looks out across the Santorini caldera in the Aegean Sea, where a future eruption could be more explosive than scientists previously thought. Over 3,000 years ago, the eruption of Santoriniâ€™s volcano ended an ancient civilization. Scientists may know what the next big explosion could look like.
The Santorini volcano gives this Greek island in the Aegean Sea its undeniable aesthetic marvel. But itâ€™s also at the center of a spectacularly violent origin story.
Arc-shaped Santorini has a flooded interior because, in the distant past, colossal eruptions have rapidly excavated a hole out of the islandâ€™s center. After each eruption, the Santorini volcano starts to recharge its magma supply, readying itself for another gigantic blast.
The most infamous of these outbursts toâ€¦

entry.title: Dinosaurs were thriving right up to the moment the asteroid hit
entry.summary:
Alamosaurus was one of the last dinosaurs from southern North American. Paleontologists have recently dated the rock formation from where it was found in New Mexico to around 340,000 years before the asteroid hit. Newly dated fossils from New Mexico challenge the idea that dinosaurs were in declineâ€”and suggest instead they had formed flourishing communities.
Around 66 million years ago, during the Northern Hemisphereâ€™s spring, a six-mile-wide asteroid struck what is now the YucatÃ¡n Peninsula. The resulting disaster drove 75 percent of Earthâ€™s species to extinction, including nearly every dinosaur lineage except for beaked birds.
The impact was devastating. Its aftermath, apocalyptic. But what was happening right before the cataclysmic event?
Paleontologists have long debaâ€¦

entry.title: Could â€˜the big oneâ€™ in Cascadia trigger the San Andreas?
entry.summary:
This satellite-based model of Earth shows the tectonic boundaries (yellow lines) in the eastern Pacific Ocean. The San Andreas Fault and the Cascadia Subduction Zone both occur along the North American plate, beside the Pacific and Juan de Fuca plates respectively. Are two of the deadliest earthquake zones in North America linked? It's possibleâ€”but controversial.
One of the most dangerous faults in the United States, the Cascadia Subduction Zone, may be able to trigger an earthquake on the San Andreas Fault, a new study says. But some scientists want more evidence.Â
According to the paper, published in September in the journal Geosphere, deep-sea sediment cores taken along the West Coast offer evidence that the two fault systems have been synced up for much of the last 2,500 yâ€¦

entry.title: Discover Oman through its perfumes and ancient aromas
entry.summary:
The fragrant resin of Boswellia Sacra trees is harvested by cutting the bark. Across Omanâ€™s mountains, wadis and coasts, the scents of rose and frankincense tell a tale that bridges the countryâ€™s past and present.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œThis perfume was first made for royalty.â€ The salesman at Amouage perfume factory in Muscat is pointing towards a 24-carat gold flask, a tiny, exquisite bottle shaped like a khanjar, Omanâ€™s traditional dagger. â€œThere are 120 ingredients in here, with two in particular that really represent Oman: rose and frankincense,â€ he says.
The fragrance house was commissioned by Omanâ€™s beloved late Sultan Qaboos bin Said al Said in 1983 and its name, Amouage, comes from the Arabic word for waves. It's fittiâ€¦

entry.title: Exploring England on two wheelsâ€”how to plan a cycle tour
entry.summary:
England is a nation of bike enthusiasts and, as a result, possesses an excellent cycling infrastructure. Two-wheeled tourers have an impressively large choice of places to ride, whether itâ€™s forests or fells, cities or cycle superhighways, canals or coasts. With the right gear and a good idea, you can zoom along wild coastlines, camp beside a Roman wall and find solitude high on windswept plains. Hereâ€™s how to plan the perfect English cycle tour.
Consider where youâ€™d like to visit and use online resources to help plan the best itinerary. Cycle.travel has a range of comprehensive guides for on- and off-road cycle touring, as well as a detailed route finder. Take a look at Sustransâ€™ National Cycle Network maps, which can also simplify planning your itinerary.
Before setting out oâ€¦

entry.title: Have orcas been sinking ships for millennia?
entry.summary:
A sixth-century Byzantine mosaic depicts an amphibious monsterâ€”though it's unclear if this is the same one that was thought to have tormented the sailors of Constantinople by attacking and sinking their boats. The historian Procopius described how a creature called Porphyrios terrified sixth-century sailors for 50 years. But what was it?
â€œIt sank many ships and troubled the passengers of many others.â€
These words sound like they could have been written about White Gladis, the orca who has earned renown in recent years as the potential ringleader of killer whales ramming boats and ripping off their rudders.
But in fact this text was written by the Greek historian Procopius, who told of a terrible sea monster called Porphyrios that tormented the people of Byzantium for 50 yâ€¦

entry.title: Worldâ€™s longest woolly rhino horn discovered in Siberia
entry.summary:
In the far-flung reaches of Yakutia, a rugged corner of Russia that bears the title of the coldest inhabited place on Earth, mysteries lurk beneath the frozen soil.
Roman Romanov, a local hunter, fisherman and fossil collector, uncovered one of those mysteries last summer. While walking along a stream in the tundra, he spotted something emerging from the melting permafrost: a skull and a massive, curved horn poking out of the ground.
Romanov dug up the frozen remains and took them to the Mammoth Museum in the regional capital of Yakutsk, where many creatures pulled from the icy ground are stored and studied. Scientists at the museum determined the skull belonged to a 19,700-year-old woolly rhino. When it roamed the area, it would have been as heavy as an SUV and cloaked in a shagâ€¦

entry.title: 9 perfect small-town getaways near Washington, D.C.
entry.summary:
Harperâ€™s Ferry, West Virginia, is situated at the junction of the Potomac and Shenandoah Rivers. Itâ€™s a town you can cover in a day, but itâ€™s worth spending an extra few days. Life moves quickly in the nationâ€™s capital. But just across the Potomac, you can trade traffic for tranquility with these storybook escapes.
In Washington, D.C., where every corner buzzes with history, politics, and the unmistakable rhythms of go-go music, life moves at full throttle. Yet just across the Potomac River and beyond the Beltway, the pulse changes. Within a few hours, you can swap the motorcades for meadows, marble monuments for main streets, and the city skyline for tranquil shorelines. While Richmond and Baltimore often top weekend travel lists, for those craving something quieter and quainter, â€¦

entry.title: Forty migrants, including children, perish in Tunisia shipwreck
entry.summary: A shipwreck off Tunisia that claimed the lives of at least 40 African migrants has once again exposed the lethal risks of irregular sea crossings on routes to Europe, the UN migration agency said on Thursday.

entry.title: Ceasefire offers â€˜lifelineâ€™ but Gaza hospitals remain in ruins
entry.summary: Gazaâ€™s health system remains in ruins despite the fragile ceasefire holding, with hundreds of thousands still facing urgent medical and humanitarian needs, the head of the World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Thursday.

entry.title: Millions pushed to â€˜brink of survivalâ€™ in Sudan
entry.summary: Over 900 days of brutal conflict, widespread human rights violations, famine, and the collapse of essential services have driven millions of people in Sudan to the â€œbrink of survivalâ€ â€“ with women and children bearing the heaviest burden.

entry.title: Fragile Gaza ceasefire marks â€˜a momentous but precarious juncture,â€™ UN envoy tells Security Council
entry.summary: The Gaza ceasefire provides a rare opportunity to end one of the most destructive phases of the wider Israel-Palestine conflict, the UNâ€™s deputy Middle East envoy told the Security Council on Thursday.

entry.title: Security Council LIVE: Gaza ceasefire, aid crisis dominates agenda as ambassadors meet on the Middle East
entry.summary: The UN Security Council is meeting in New York to debate the Middle East. The session comes amid faltering progress on the fragile Gaza ceasefire and mounting humanitarian needs after two years of war, with famine still looming in parts of the territory. Ambassadors will likely discuss yesterday's ICJ advisory opinion affirming Israelâ€™s obligation to allow agencies aid access under international law. Follow our in-depth live coverage from 10am; UN News app users can go here.

entry.title: Mentoring Under Pressure: How One Nigerian Woman Is Shaping the Next Generation of Investigative Reporters
entry.summary: Through her two-plus decades of mentoring young journalists, Joke Kujenya has left a legacy of fostering and strengthening investigative reporting in a difficult press climate.

entry.title: 'Java Man,â€™ the first Homo erectus discovered, is finally going home
entry.summary:
The skull cap of 'Java Man' was discovered by EugÃ¨ne Dubois in 1891 in Trinil, East Java. It played a crucial role in our understanding of human evolution, and will be repatriated to Indonesia after more than a century in the Netherlands. Excavated with colonial labor and shipped to the Netherlands, the famous fossil is being repatriated to Indonesia along with 28,000 other fossils.
In 1866 Raden Saleh, a Javanese nobleman and naturalist painter, traveled to the eastern part of Java to see the so-called â€œbattlefield of the giants.â€
Local farmers there had found massive bones, which they said belonged to the giant demon king Arimba, a figure from the Javanese version of the Sanskrit epic, Mahabharata. Intrigued, Saleh visited â€œthe battlefieldâ€ and identified the large bones as â€¦

entry.title: The striking ways that playing golf reshapes your body and brain
entry.summary:
Retirees play golf in Sun City, Arizona. Although it may seem like a leisurely pastime, studies show that golf offers a complete full-body workout that can even extend your life. Studies show that spending time on the links offers real benefits for cardiovascular health, cognition, and lifespan. â€œThe message is clear: Play golf and live longer.â€
Golf may look like a leisurely pastime, but donâ€™t be fooled by the unhurried pace or neatly trimmed greens. Beneath its calm exterior lies one of the most unexpectedly complete workouts and wellness boosts around.
â€œOver 100 million peopleÂ worldwide now play golf, which is great for both individual and public health,â€ says Julia Kettinen, an exercise medicine lecturer at the University of Eastern Finlandâ€™s School of Medicine. â€œThe magicâ€¦

entry.title: Lucid dreams can help reduce anxiety. Hereâ€™s how.
entry.summary:
Lucid dreaming is the state of becoming aware of one's dream as it occurs. Lucid dreaming has been shown to reduce insomnia and anxiety, and even help people process their grief. But for most of us, it doesnâ€™t come naturally.
A lucid dream is one in which the person is aware that theyâ€™re dreaming and can either exert some control over the dream, or passively observe its unfolding while maintaining awareness that itâ€™s a dream. Some liken it to being in a movie and watching a movie at the same time.
Lucid dreamers have an opportunity to potentially influence their dream life, perhaps by consciously interrupting a nighttime narrative to rescript a new outcome. This can be especially helpful for reducing the frequency of nightmares in those who have them, according to research in â€¦

entry.title: Where to find the best sausage stands in Vienna
entry.summary:
Wieners are taken seriously in the Austrian capital as sausage stands like Wiener WÃ¼rstelstand serve their hot dogs alongside open mic nights and dance battles. Once a humble pit stop, the cityâ€™s sausage stands â€” now inscribed on UNESCOâ€™s Intangible Cultural Heritage list â€” are reimagining tradition through bold flavours and contemporary flair.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œWÃ¼rstelstÃ¤ndes are the heart of Vienna,â€ says Sebastian Neuschler, owner of Alles Wurscht, one of the cityâ€™s new-wave sausage stands, set just behind the Vienna Stock Exchange building. â€œThey allow people, from small children to 90-year-old grandmothers, to meet and connect â€” bringing the city together.â€
Viennaâ€™s passion for sausages was ignited in 1805Â when Germanâ€¦

entry.title: Been to Lisbon and Porto? Hereâ€™s where to go next
entry.summary:
Beyond the beaten path lie Portugalâ€™s best-kept secrets, where hot springs still steam, ancient towers guard cork forests and rugged trails wind through volcanic craters. From the reviving spas of Chaves to the street art of Viseu, these lesser-known destinations offer truly memorable stays.
Best for: Bohemian beach days Tucked between pine groves and rice paddies an hour south of Lisbon, secluded Comporta has a laid-back rhythm beloved by celebrities and royals. Slow days are spent cycling boardwalks to empty beaches, sipping white port cocktails beneath cork oaks, and browsing ateliers in Casa da Cultura for linen fashion and hand-thrown ceramics. Dine on garlic clams at Sal or traditional Alentejo bread stew with rock lobster at Jncquoi Beach Club, then watch flamingos sweep acroâ€¦

entry.title: Which alcohol is the â€˜healthiestâ€™? Scientists have an answer.
entry.summary:
Marketed as low-calorie and hangover-proof, tequila has been reimagined as a â€œcleanâ€ spirit. But research shows that the body processes all alcohol the same wayâ€”no matter the source. This popular spirit been touted as health-consciousâ€”low in sugar, hangover-proof, and even â€œclean.â€ We asked experts to separate fact from fiction.
There are several unwritten â€œrulesâ€ when it comes to alcohol: whiskey makes you aggressive, wine turns you emotional, and tequila? Itâ€™s the devil in a bottle.
But in recent years, tequilaâ€™s reputation has shifted. Once the fuel of spring-break regrets, itâ€™s now touted as the â€œcleanestâ€ option at the barâ€”low-calorie, additive-free, and even hangover-proof. But is there really such a thing as a healthier alcohol?
David Jernigan, assistant dean of puâ€¦

entry.title: Security Council LIVE: UN discusses next phase to curb Haiti gang violence, step up aid
entry.summary: Following renewal of the Security Councilâ€™s sanctions regime in Haiti and a resolution to create a new Gang Suppression Force to combat the scourge of gang violence, ambassadors heard this afternoon from the top UN official in the country. In his first briefing as head of the UN office in Haiti (BINUH), Carlos Ruiz Massieu reported on latest developments, as brutal violence and insecurity continues to rage, increasing pressure on diplomats to act fast and decisively to protect millions of Haitians facing impunity and chaos. UN News app users can follow live coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israel is obliged to let aid flow into Occupied Palestinian Territory, says World Court
entry.summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) says that Israel must uphold its responsibilities as the â€œoccupying powerâ€ by ensuring aid can flow freely and by respecting the rights of the UN and other humanitarian agencies working in the Occupied Palestinian Territory.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Most major methane leak alerts ignored despite climate threat
entry.summary: UN satellite tracking has greatly improved detection of major methane leaks â€“ a gas responsible for about a third of global warming â€“ yet companies and governments are acting on only around 12 per cent of alerts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Four winters on, UN in Ukraine continues to deliver aid under fire
entry.summary: As Ukraine enters its fourth winter since the beginning of the full-scale Russian invasion in 2022, the United Nations remains committed to providing aid for embattled civilians across the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New forum builds on Sevilla pledges to tackle global debt crisis
entry.summary: A new UN-backed forum launched on Wednesday to help developing nations escape the weight of unsustainable debt â€“ which has left more than three billion people worldwide living in economies forced to spend more on repayments than health or education.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Climate science and early warnings key to saving lives
entry.summary: No country is safe from the devastating impacts of extreme weather â€” and saving lives means making early-warning systems accessible to all, UN chief AntÃ³nio Guterres said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

Why Vancouver is the outdoorsy escape you should take in 2026
entry.summary: The sprawling Stanley Park National Historic Site is a 1,000-acre natural escape with trails, gardens, and an aquarium. British Columbiaâ€™s biggest city is co-hosting the FIFA World Cup in 2026â€”but thatâ€™s only one reason to visit. Here are the best places to eat, where to stay, and how to explore this gem in 2026. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html British Columbiaâ€™s biggest city is a rugged, outdoorsy, escape. Set on the edge of the Pacific Ocean, it boasts breaching orcas and massive humpback whales, towering Douglas firs, the sky-scraping North Shore Mountains, and thousands of acres of natural parkland. Sustainability filters naturally into every facet of daily life, and Indigenous tourism offerings placâ€¦

entry.title: Witness an incredible wildlife win at this Rwandan park
entry.summary:
Home to the Big Five, Akagera National Park is also home to nearly 500 species of birds. Lions, white rhinos, elephants, and giraffes have been reintroduced to a park that was once nearly devastated by civil war. Learn how to plan your trip to see the Big Five here, from where to stay to when to go. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Mist clings to the Mutumba Hills, as lakes and rivers wind through sprawling, acacia-dotted savannah. In Akagera National Park, a natural refuge in northeastern Rwanda where wilderness meets resilience, adventure waits around every corner.
Established in 1934, Akagera National Park was nearly devastated by Rwandaâ€™s civil war in the 1990s. As displaced populations were reseâ€¦

entry.title: Why you should visit the rugged North Dakota Badlands in 2026
entry.summary: The Theodore Roosevelt Presidential Library is set to open in July 2026 outside Medora, North Dakota. Discover the best seasons to visit, where to stay near Theodore Roosevelt National Park, and how to explore this otherworldly landscape. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Theodore Roosevelt first traveled to the Badlands on a hunting trip in 1883. He was so taken by the otherworldly landscape of pastel buttes, trilling meadowlarks, and disappearing bison, that he returned in 1884 to grieve the simultaneous deaths of his wife and mother, raising cattle and working on the wild frontier for almost three years. Its â€œdesolate, grim beautyâ€ so changed Roosevelt that he famously wrote, â€œI would not have been presâ€¦

The city that has reinvented itself across dynasties has no shortage of new must-see attractions in 2026. Hereâ€™s how to see the best of Beijing, from the Forbidden City to its hidden courtyards and alleyways. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Beijingâ€™s story is a long arc of transformationâ€”a city that has reinvented itself across dynasties and decades, transforming from an imperial capital to a global metropolis. Beijing has sometimes fought for its image, but anyone who has spent time here knows that the cityâ€™s appeal doesnâ€™t lie in a flashy skyline or international influence, but rather in its unassuming corner restaurants wheâ€¦

entry.title: Hull, Yorkshireâ€”an English port town with a defiant spirit
entry.summary:
Hullâ€™s maritime heritage is apparent year-round, though visitors in July can attend the annual Hull Folk & Maritime Festival. With 800 years of maritime history, this northern town is going all in on its seafaring past in 2026 with revamped museums, docks, and preserved ships. See why its laid-back charm is so hard to resist. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Turn any corner in Hull and thereâ€™ll be a homage to its 800 years of British maritime heritage. A weathervane in the form of an 18th-century sail ship; an elaborate coat of arms with an upturned anchor above a Georgian shipping office; or even herring carved into the pavements around the old docks.
Life in this northern city on the â€¦

entry.title: Why 2026 is the time to experience Rio
entry.summary: Hike or take the train up to the 98-foot-tall Cristo Redentor (Christ the Redeemer). With its alluring beaches and lush mountains, Rio doesnâ€™t need to do much to convince people to visit. But in 2026, this irrepressible city has some new surprises up its sleeve. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Many a serenade has been sung about Rio de Janeiroâ€™s alluring beaches, its passionate people, and stunning vistas, enticing visitors to this fun-loving Brazilian city for well over a century. But Rio has revealed a few more reasons to visitÂ in 2026. The National Museum of Brazil Museu Nacional/UFRJ) is pushing for a second temporary reopening then, and a full reopening in 2028, following the tragic 2018 fâ€¦

New developments are shining a spotlight on Indigenous culture in Canadaâ€™s biggest provinceâ€”an area that encompasses cobblestone streets, boreal forests, Arctic tundra, glacier-carved fjords, and thousands of lakes. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html With its French-speaking inhabitants and Old World architecture, QuÃ©bec (so the well-worn observation goes) can feel like a slice of Europe in North America. Beyond the flagship cities of MontrÃ©al and QuÃ©bec City, QuÃ©becâ€™s vast landscapes encompass boreal forest, Arctic tunâ€¦

entry.title: This Australian park tells an ancientâ€”and sacredâ€”story
entry.summary: Uluru, a sandstone monolith, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It is a sacred place to the Indigenous Anangu people, who have lived here for more than 30,000 years. Formed more than 500 million years ago, this landâ€”home to the oldest living culture in the worldâ€”tells an ancient story. Learn why 2026 is the time to visit, and how to explore it respectfully. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Uluru and Kata Tjuta were formed over 500 million years ago, and these living landscapes have been sacred to the Indigenous people for tens of thousands of years. Uluru is one of the worldâ€™s largest monoliths, and each mark, watering hole, and cave tells an ancient story. Neighboring Kata Tjutaâ€™s domes inspire its nâ€¦

entry.title: Why Oaxacaâ€™s coast is Mexicoâ€™s next breakout region
entry.summary: In Oaxaca, November to April is the dry season, when the ocean is calmer and the skies are clearer. Once remote and difficult to reach, Oaxacaâ€™s wild Costa Chica is now more accessible than ever. Find the best times to visit, where to surf, which â€œmagical townsâ€ to explore, and more. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Until recently, Oaxacaâ€™s Costa Chica, or â€œsmall coast,â€ was remote and hard to reach. Known for its famous surf and series of bohemian, countercultural enclaves, this stretch of wild coastline is defined by nature: Migrating whales, endangered sea turtles, some 300 species of endemic birds, phosphorescent lagoons, and impressive Pacific swells. But the relative difficulty of reaching this regiâ€¦

entry.title: Everyone wants to visit South Korea nowâ€”and so should you
entry.summary: Thereâ€™s no doubt about itâ€”South Korea is one of the worldâ€™s â€œitâ€ destinations. The countryâ€™s new-found mega-popularity has found itself propelled by the music, films, and drama series of the â€œKorean Wave,â€ whose ripples only seem to increase in size every year. Even before visiting, many also find themselves addicted to Koreaâ€™s famously spicy cuisine, with dishes such as bibimbap and japchaeâ€”as well as side-dishes like kimchi, and alcoholic drinks such as soju and makgeolliâ€”becoming increasingly popular worldwide. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html While Seoul and Busan are as modern as cities come, Korea is also a proudly traditional land, with unique culture and customs resulting from its two-millennium-longâ€¦

entry.title: How to visit Maui responsibly in 2026
entry.summary:
Maui is rebuilding and recovering from the devastating 2023 wildfires. Itâ€™s not just a vacationâ€”itâ€™s an investment in the islandâ€™s future. Learn the best times to travel, where to stay, and how to best support local communities and honor Hawaiian culture. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html In 2023, wildfires devastated the Hawaiian island of Maui, destroying much of the historic town of LÄhainÄ along with parts of the island's "upcountry." But now, over two years later, Maui is calling visitors back with gusto.
For some time after the fires, tourismâ€”Mauiâ€™s largest economy driverâ€”dwindled, first from pausing entirely, and later, as a result of tourists who shied away either out of an overabundance of seâ€¦

entry.title: Why Dominica is the Caribbean island you should visit in 2026
entry.summary:
Dominica is home to whales, UNESCO World Heritage Sites, a new cable car, and stunning beaches. Travelers will be able to experience the pristine beauty of the Caribbeanâ€™s Nature Island in new ways in 2026. Hereâ€™s our guide to where to stay, what to eat, and what to do. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Dominica fully lives up to its self-appointed nickname as the "Caribbeanâ€™s Nature Island." In a region that brims with pristine beaches requiring nothing more but to show up and relax, Dominica inspires travelers to get up and get moving.
Rainforests blanket two-thirds of the island, and geothermal hot springs and waterfalls provide plenty of opportunity to walk, run, and take a cool dip. Singular geolâ€¦

entry.title: Yamagata Prefecture might just be Japanâ€™s best-kept secret
entry.summary: At night, the Zao Snow Monsters are illuminated with colored lights so visitors can continue to marvel them after dark. While the crowds continue to gather in Tokyo and Kyoto, now is the right time to venture off the beaten path to rural hot spring towns that look like a fairy taleâ€”and happen to have some of the best sake and ramen in Japan. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html As Japanâ€™s tourism hot spots attract more and more travelers, thereâ€™s never been a better time to go off the beaten path and explore relatively under-visited places like Yamagata Prefecture. While more than half of the 37 million visitors to Japan in 2024 spent some time in Tokyo and a third visited Kyoto, around one percent made theirâ€¦

entry.title: Why Oklahomaâ€™s Route 66 is the ultimate American road trip
entry.summary: A restored service station on Route 66 in Hydro, Oklahoma. Route 66 is celebrating its 100th anniversary in 2026. As the iconic highway turns 100, see why a drive along this stretch of the Mother Road is like traveling through time. Find the best time to go, which nostalgic inns to stay at, and the iconic stops you canâ€™t miss. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html As Route 66 gears up to celebrate 100 years of kicks, Oklahomaâ€™s stretch is streets ahead in terms of revitalization. A well-oiled campaign has restored mid-century landmarks, while welcoming a few plucky newcomers. These days, cruising the route feels much like time travelingâ€”back to an era when the car was king and families piled into chrome-finnedâ€¦

entry.title: Why you should visit TÃ¼rkiyeâ€™s Black Sea coast in 2026
entry.summary:
SÃ¼mela Monastery is renowned for its early Christian frescoes. This lush, scenic region is still under the radarâ€”but not for much longer. Learn why travelers seeking authentic Turkish culture are heading north in 2026. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html With around 60 million visitors each year, TÃ¼rkiye is now the worldâ€™s fourth-most popular tourist destination. Nearly all of those travelers pass through Istanbul or laze along fabulous Aegean and Mediterranean beaches. But one corner of the Eurasian nation continues to fly beneath the radarâ€”the long, lush, and scenic Black Sea Coast in the northeast.
That probably wonâ€™t be for long. More flights from Istanbul and other major cities, rapidly improving tâ€¦

entry.title: Why trigger points cause so much painâ€”and how you can relieve it
entry.summary:
A trigger point is a discrete, hyperirritable nodule (like a â€œknotâ€) that is palpable in a taut band of muscleâ€”and it can produce pain in a particular spot or in another part of the body. Most people experience it as an ache or a stab of pain when these locations are touched or pressed.
Recently, trigger points have been implicated in various conditions, including myofascial pain syndrome (a chronic disorder involving the muscles and the surrounding connective tissue); tension-type headaches (particularly in women);Â migraine headaches; chronic neck pain; and low back pain.
While the formal term â€œmyofascial trigger pointâ€ was coined in the 1950s, research investigating the underlying causes and effective treatments is relatively new.
Thatâ€™s a positive development because trigâ€¦

entry.title: What it takes to be Americaâ€™s top house cat
entry.summary:
Walking into the 2025 Cat Fancier Association International Cat Show & Expo, there is no mistaking where you are.Â
On the main stage, performers belt out Taylor Swiftâ€™s song â€œ22,â€ but they have replaced the lyrics with meowsâ€”itâ€™s â€œCat-aoke,â€ after allâ€”and they are joined by a trio of dancing, cat-themed Furries. Nearby, thereâ€™s a four-foot-tall cat tower with two adult humans sitting atop cosplaying as Rum Tum Tugger and Electra from the Broadway musicalÂ Cats. They mew as I walk past.Â
Vendors sell cat houses that look like more like condos, or even the White House. A booth demonstrates a $900 futuristic-looking box that promises to dry your freshly-bathed pet quickly and quietly.Â
It's cats all the way down here at one of the largest cat shows on the planet, organized by thâ€¦

The post Growing Share of U.S. Adults Say Religion Is Gaining Influence in American Life appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: What it takes to tend the worldâ€™s deadliest garden
entry.summary:
The keepers of a poison gardenÂ on the grounds next to Alnwick Castle in Northumberland, England, anticipate a great many fainters every year. The garden, the largest of its kind, sits behind stately iron gates embellished with skulls and is packed with more than a hundred varieties of plants so deadly that you canâ€™t enter without supervision.
As tours set off, guides warn visitors not to touch, lick, or pick as they learn about poisoners from history and see the brews and cuttings that served as their weapons of choice. Thereâ€™s the Teacup Poisoner, who kicked off his infamous murder spree by dosing his sister withÂ Atropa belladonna.Â And Doctor Death, a physician convicted of murdering 15 of his patients with a drug derived from the opium poppy. Every so oftenâ€”crunch!â€”another guest hitâ€¦

entry.title: 8 of Brazil's best festivals beyond Rio
entry.summary:
Elaborately costumed Samba dancers are the stars of Rio de Janeiro's many street festivals and parties. Brazil is passionate about celebrations, its enormous cultural diversity resulting in a rich calendar of events held throughout the year â€” here are some of the ones to look forward to beyond Rio.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In a country known for celebrations â€“ chief among them the Rio Carnival, which takes place annually between February and March â€“ thereâ€™s plenty to look forward to throughout the year. From the riotous to the muddy, here are some of the best festivals and celebrations.
This unique festival, held in the photogenic Costa Verde town of Paraty, coincides with Rioâ€™s Carnival but couldnâ€™t be more different. Instead oâ€¦

entry.summary: The UN on Monday said it was encouraged by renewed Gaza ceasefire commitments, warning that recent violence risked undermining fragile progress, as recovery efforts â€“ including a large-scale rubble removal project â€“ slowly gain momentum across the war-ravaged enclave.

entry.title: Britain's bonfire night events worth travelling for
entry.summary:
This raucous, torch-lit parade in Lewes features brass bands, bagpipes and firecrackers as well as a procession of giant, caricature effigies. Get winter off to a cracking start with our pick of the November festivities, from fireworks in London to flaming tar barrels in Devon.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
â€˜Remember, remember, the fifth of Novemberâ€™, goes the old nursery rhyme, â€˜gunpowder, treason and plot.â€™ Itâ€™s a memorably succinct summary of the events of that very night in 1605, when Catholic rebel Guy Fawkes tried to blow up the Houses of Parliament and assassinate Englandâ€™s Protestant king, James I. The monarchâ€™s survival has been marked ever since and celebrations have evolved over the centuries. Traditionally, Guyâ€™s effigy was burnâ€¦

entry.title: The Louvre has a wild history of being robbed in broad daylight
entry.summary:
People gather around the Mona Lisa painting in Paris, three years after it was stolen from the Louvre by Vincenzo Peruggia in 1911. The theft is one of the most famous in the museum's history. One of the most infamous heists in the cultural institutionâ€™s history was the 1911 theft of the Mona Lisaâ€”when Pablo Picasso numbered among the suspects.
It took just four minutes for a group of audacious thieves to pull off what may have been one of the most daring crimes in modern art: the theft of Napoleonic-era jewels from the Louvre in Paris on the morning of October 19.
The heist, which took place while the museum was open to the public, involved a variety of jewels once owned by members of the French monarchy, including an emerald necklace and earrings that Napoleon gave his sâ€¦

entry.title: Chasing rhythms in Detroitâ€”inside the city's vibrant music scene
entry.summary: Thanks to the revolution of the motorcar assembly line, Detroit became the beating heart of American industry in the 20th century â€” ranking among the richest cities in the world. Beyond industry, the Motor City has long been a beacon of creativity, with a conveyor belt of musical talent that never stopped rolling. From soul-stirring legends such as Aretha Franklin and Stevie Wonder to modern icons such as Eminem and The White Stripes, this Midwestern city gifted the world some of its brightest musical stars. Today, that creative energy still pulses through Detroit â€” not just in music, but in the bold flavours of its burgeoning restaurant scene and a flourishing street art movement that draws in visitors from around the world. Through it all, the Motor City keeps on moving and grooving to tâ€¦

entry.title: What happened the last time the French crown jewels were stolen
entry.summary:
Known by awed gemologists simply as â€œthe Blue,â€ the worldâ€™s biggest blue diamond first vanished in a jewel heist during the turmoil of revolutionary Paris in 1792. Since then, it has resurfaced and disappeared several times around Europe and across the Atlantic. Historians and jewelers have finally ended this treasure hunt that lasted more than two centuries.
Most diamonds are prized for colorlessness, but this remarkable gem stood out for its distinctive deep blue hue. Discovered in India and brought to France in the 17th century, the stone measured a whopping 115 caratsâ€”a rare heavyweight in gemological terms.
The diamond came to the attention of Franceâ€™s Louis XIV, who bought it in 1668. To craft a fitting symbol for the Sun King, Louis had it cut, reducing it to 69 caratsâ€¦

entry.title: How to plan the perfect French Riviera tour by train
entry.summary:
Mentonâ€™s old town overlooks the Mediterranean and welcomed the first sleeper train passengers on the French Riviera in 1886. Take the train for a laid-back tour of the CÃ´te dâ€™Azurâ€™s glitzy cities and lesser-known towns, jumping off to buy a slice of PissaladiÃ¨re, visit a museum or dip your toes in the sea.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In 1886, passengers on the Calais-MÃ©diterranÃ©e Express were among the first to ride a sleeper service from Paris to the town of Menton on the French Riviera. They bedded down in the capital and woke up speeding along the coast, prickly pears blooming by the tracks, flashes of the Mediterranean sparkling in the first light of morning. The train was discontinued some 20 years ago, but with sleeper services enjâ€¦
